claims.text: Egg prices fell 12.7% last month, the biggest monthly decline since 1984.
claims.context: Bureau of Labor Statistics report, recent data.

claims.text: Egg prices fell 12.7% last month, the biggest monthly decline since 1984.

claim_reports.claim_text: Egg prices fell 12.7% last month, the biggest monthly decline since 1984.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that egg prices fell by 12.7% last month, marking the largest monthly decline since 1984, as reported by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.

supports.title: US Retail Egg Prices Fell 12.7% in April - Farm Policy News
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that egg prices fell by 12.7% last month, marking the largest monthly decline since 1984, as reported by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
supports.snippet: The average price for a dozen Grade A eggs declined to $5.12 last month after reaching a record $6.23 in March, according to the US Bureau of Labor Statistics.

supports.title: April CPI inflation report: Egg prices decline for first time in months
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that egg prices fell by 12.7% last month, marking the largest monthly decline since 1984, as stated in the Google snippet.
supports.snippet: Overall, grocery prices fell 0.4% last month, pulled down in part by the big 12.7% drop in the price of eggs. It was the biggest drop in food ...

supports.title: Egg prices see largest monthly drop since 1984, further decline ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that egg prices in the United States fell by 12.7% last month, marking the largest monthly decline since 1984, as reported by CNN.
supports.snippet: Egg prices in the United States experienced a dramatic 12.7% decline last month, according to a Tuesday report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

mixed.title: U.S. egg prices fall for the first time in months but remain near ... - NPR
mixed.evidence_summary: The article confirms that egg prices fell to $5.12 last month, marking a significant decline from the previous record of $6.23 in March, but does not specify the percentage of the decline or its historical context since 1984.
mixed.snippet: The average price for a dozen Grade A eggs declined to $5.12 last month after reaching a record $6.23 in March, according to the U.S. Bureau of ...

unclear.title: Eggs are finally getting cheaper as prices sink the most since 1984
unclear.evidence_summary: The Bureau of Labor Statistics' egg price index fell about 13% over the month in April, the biggest decline since March 1984.
unclear.snippet: The Bureau of Labor Statistics' egg price index fell about 13% over the month in April, the biggest decline since March 1984.

transcript_data.text: Trump's egg price warning comes true. Reality hits home. For months, President Donald Trump has falsely claimed that egg prices are tumbling. It wasn't true then, but it's true now. Egg prices fell 12.7% last month, the biggest monthly decline since 1984. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Tuesday, and they could continue to fall this month, too. The USDA reported last week that a dozen large white shell eggs now cost $330 on average, down a whopping 69 from a week before. It's a remarkable reversal after egg prices surged in each of the past 5 months and 17 of the past 19 months because of a deadly aven flu epidemic that necessitated the mass culling of egg laying hens. Maybe the worst of egg gate has passed. Tyler Shipper, associate professor in economics and data analysis at the University of St. Thomas in St. Paul, Minnesota, told CNN. Nevertheless, egg prices remain significantly higher now than before the latest bird flu outbreak, and they cost 49.3% more last month than they did a year earlier. Eggs are still more expensive than when Trump took office, according to the BLS. Egg prices this past Easter, which typically rise in the run-up to the holiday, were the highest for any Easter on record, the USDA reported. Well, before last month's decline, Trump had been touting falling egg prices as a sign that his administration's plan to lower prices for consumers has been working. In February, the USDA announced an initiative to lower egg prices, including increased biocurity on egg laying farms, aid to farmers who have lost flocks and temporary lifting of restrictions on egg imports. Despite agriculture secretary Brooke Rollins far more conservative estimate that egg prices would normalize in the summer, Trump last month said, "As you know, the cost of eggs has come down like 93 94% since we took office. Those percentage declines, Trump stated, are not close to accurate. But we now know that consumer egg prices were indeed falling sharply when Trump made those remarks. The consumer price index data wasn't out yet to confirm or deny Trump's claims. It appears as though Trump may have been talking about wholesale prices, which had been tumbling throughout March before normalizing in recent weeks. Nevertheless, wholesale prices fell by half, not close to the 90% plus figures Trump was citing. Wholesale prices are the costs distributors pay to farmers or middlemen. Consumer prices are what customers pay at grocery stores. Those costs typically make their way through the supply chain at a slower pace because grocery stores may decide to keep prices at a certain price even when wholesale prices change to try to recoup loss profits from prior weeks according to Kevin Bergquist, sector manager at Wells Fargo Agri Food Institute. from prior weeks. According to Kevin Bergquist, sector manager at Wells Fargo Agri Food Institute, the USDA says consumer prices finally fell as demand for eggs decreased and aven flu cases have fallen. Many groceries, including large chains like Costco, had limited customers purchases because of egg shortages. So, Trump's claim that consumer egg prices are down is finally true, even if the timing of his claim and the wild percentages he threw around were grossly inaccurate. Don't forget to like and subscribe. Thanks.
